results.title: Child care and development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Child development series”.
The film gives overall consideration to the habits of daily physical care that ensure a happy, healthy child. Correct attitudes and procedures toward establishing good habits of eating, sleeping, and bathing are covered. Stresses the elements of good diet. The question of proper clothing - warm and light for the infant, sturdy and functional for the toddler - is explored. Raises the important consideration of suitable and becoming clothing as exerting considerable psychological influence on personality development. The importance of outdoor exercise is stressed. The film shows the importance of the attitudes of both parents and children towards good routines of daily living.

group_works.title: Clash (TEFC)
group_works.creator_credit: Carol Haslam and Open University

results.title: Clash (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Child Care and Development”.
Coming up to the age of two, children are really beginning to assert their independence and this can often lead to a clash of will with their parents. The film looks at a wide range of different incidents involving children of this age and viewers are asked to decide what they would do if they were the parents.

group_works.title: Jamie, Ethan and Marlon: the first two months
group_works.creator_credit: Robert Humble, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Jamie, Ethan and Marlon: the first two months
results.creator_credit: Robert Humble, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Child”.
He has just made his debut into the world. How does he shape up? In this first film, a pediatrician explains what he looks for when he gives a newborn infant his first physical checkup—testing reflexes, muscle tone, eye movement, etc. Three babies are observed, first in hospital, then at home in the care of their parents.

results.title: Vibration of molecules
results.creator_credit: Gerald Nevius and Sutherland Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study”
Explains the relationship between the structure of a molecule and its vibrational motions. Water, carbon dioxide, and methane are discussed in detail. The effect of molecular collision, or absorption of light, on molecular vibrations is illustrated.

results.title: Vanadium: a transition element
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Wexler Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Eipsode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study”
Vanadium is studied as a typical transition element. The different oxidation states of vanadium and their colours are observed and then identified by means of a quantitative titration of vanadium(II) solution with cerium(IV) solution. The oxidation states and the observed colours are correlated with the electronic structures using an orbital board. The formation of complex ions containing vanadium in different oxidation states is demonstrated. The variations in properties in terms of ion size and charge density are discussed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Wexler Film Productions

results.title: Synthesis of an organic compound
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Wexler Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study”
Shows the synthesis of 2-butanone, a ketone, from 2-butanol, an alcohol, as an example of a common type of organic synthesis. Discusses three basic steps: synthesis, purification, identification. In the synthesis, 2-butanol is oxidised by sodium dichromate and sulphuric acid to yield 2-butanone. Purification is accomplished by solvent extraction, followed by distillation of the 2-butanone. The identity of the product is established by forming a solid derivative of the 2-butanone and determining its melting point, and is confirmed by infrared spectroscopy
results.creator_credit_for_label: J. Arthur Campbell, David W. Ridgway and Wexler Film Productions

results.title: Shapes and polarities of molecules
results.creator_credit: National Science Foundation and Norman Wright Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemical Education Material Study Series”.
Observations of electrical effects lead to the concept of molecular polarity. Covalent substances give two types of results: some show marked interactions with electric charges, others give little effect. A model is developed based on polar and non-polar molecules. The molecular dipole model is extended to explain differences in solubility, conductivity and chemical reactivity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: National Science Foundation and Norman Wright Productions
